that's going to happen things are definitely going to slip through and we're going to do our best and we'll talk about that today but I think it's
important to recognize that it's too much pressure to say that we're going to catch everything in code review other things that are important not to build
awareness get a real security culture going and some other speakers have been talking about that today threat modeling
is a great tool for understanding what it is that you actually have that other people might want to take from you
penetration testing of course and static analysis which can even be built into the code review process there are some
great tools for that number one feel free to stop me at any time for questions or if I'm talking too
fast or anything where is the input going so the number one trick that we have
hackers using is to put some malicious input into our system somehow and when you're reviewing some code and
code review could mean a number of different things it could be you reviewing a pull request that someone on your team has opened it could be you
reviewing your own code before you offer it to merge it into your team it could be you reviewing the code of the person
right sitting right next to you because they've asked you to look at something or it could be a pair of people working
on some code together and trying to decide whether it's secure or not um so the first question to ask is is
there any new input is there anything that we need to be suspicious about have we changed the way that the input is
handled in any way are we doing something with that input that we didn't need to didn't used to do we should ask
ourselves where it's stored is it going into a database what kind of database if it was going in the database and now
it's going into the logs and the database what should we be thinking about in that particular case and then lastly how it's
used later lots of injection attacks are less about getting the insecure code into your system and more about how that
might be used later um to exploit it in for example a cross-site scripting attack so I did a secure coding course with
Stanford a couple years ago and um I learned a lot of things that I didn't know and I learned a lot of things that
I'm not sure I'll ever need um it was a good mix I think of like some some fairly technical things and
some things that really resonated with me the um the main thing that I wanted you to take
away from this slide is the idea that in this basic example here you've got a memory stack and an attacker is going
to inject some sort of instruction in there that is going to trick the um the
processor into thinking that some data is something some data is actually an
instruction because the data has overflowed into the instructional portion of the code memory and this is a
very common approach it's uh how we get cross-site scripting it's exactly the same kind of attack you're putting some
malicious JavaScript into someone's database they're going to put on the screen later number two are the right Triple A checks
in place so there are the Triple A's here are authentication have we checked that the person is who they say they are
and more than that have we checked that they still are who they say they are after they've logged in so we need some
sort of token of identifying whether someone it has securely logged into your system secondly have we checked the right
things for authorization so authorization is are they allowed to do what they're here to do so that might be
a really basic example is maybe you have some admin functionality on your website but an ordinary user shouldn't be
allowed to do that so when we're reviewing code it's important to check have we for this particular piece of functionality ensure that only the right
people can take the the actions that they need to and lastly auditing and this is the one that's
often forgotten and this is all about making sure that we know that something has happened if it is
noteworthy so it's all kind of about taking notes of important things has someone changed their password when did
they do that what country were they in when they did that how many times have they done that recently
and the important thing to learn with this is to apply the principle of least privilege so when you're looking at a
piece of code that you're reviewing think about have we implemented the
principle of least privilege which basically means have we made sure that only the people or only the system actors that absolutely have to are
allowed to take the action that we're looking at on the code thirdly have the assets changed so um
the first kind of thing with gdpr is that we have to ask ourselves has the um
do we have the consent and the legitimate interest um to process a piece of data so what that essentially means is that if
someone is trusting us with their data they need to have said yes you may have this data and secondly we need to have a
real legal reason to process that data so if for example we're running an online dating site we have a legitimate
interest to have that person's first name surname email address and a photograph of them but we might not have
a legitimate interest to have any medical information about them and what's interesting about gdpr is
it's it's all about the nature of the assets and we need to think about whether we're storing those
um are we storing any special information and I'll show you some definitions of special information in a second but the three kind of broad
examples in gdpr are personally identifiable information so that's information that I can use to figure out
who you are whether that's your name or not um so like your address
um or maybe a few places where you've worked special category data so this is data
like um your ethnic origin religious or political beliefs whether you're part of
a trade Union pieces of information like that that might be sensitive and lastly criminal
offense States as well and so when you're looking at a piece of code it's not only about looking to see okay we
have a set of practices in place for making sure that we look after data now a new piece of information comes
into our system let's say previously we didn't process any health information but now we do that's protected under
gdpr and suddenly the whole way that we look after data needs to change in respect of it we can no longer just put
it in our database we need to put it into an encrypted database as a simple example and so when you're reviewing a
pull request it's not only about the code directly in front of you it's about knowing what other parts of the system are in play and whether they offer the
kinds of protections that the data needs if the assets of kind of class of the data has changed
so here are some examples I mentioned some of these already genetic data biometric data Health sex life and
sexual orientation or some of the ones that I didn't all right number four have are we leaking any data and so this is quite a
common exploit if you have an API that offers information about your system is your API providing more information
that your client needs so let's say you have a web application you make an API request to get some information let's
say for our online dating example and you get back a bunch of information that you don't really need for a page
where you're just listing profiles so you're listing profiles you've got someone's first name you've got their surname and you've got a URL to a
picture of them but maybe you're also pulling down their address or their email address
um even when that's not strictly necessary and it becomes very easy to scrape that web page and get a bunch of information about your users
um are you logging stuff you shouldn't this is something that I've seen people run into I've I have seen more than once
user cookies being logged in the logs which would make it trivial for anyone who works at a company to go and pull
out use a cookie and impersonator user and so think very carefully about what you put in the logs you shouldn't be
putting any special category data in your logs because maybe you have a super secure mongodb instance where you're
putting people's genetic information and their email address but then you're just putting it in plain text in the log
somewhere at the same time so it's worth thinking about and the Golden Rule here is don't keep anything that you don't
need because honestly data is a liability really simple code example and the
dating profile one we spoke about if we're fetching a profile out of the database and we're returning it don't just return the whole profile grab the
two pieces of information that you're interested in out of that and return it to your client
number five are there any new dependencies so as you might have been able to tell by my open source interests

talking about it a supply chain attack in the context of um of information security what we're talking about is
someone injecting some code or behavior into your system from somewhere further down the line so it's not in the
application that you're working in but it's code or behavior that you're inheriting because of your dependencies
um and when you're busy looking at a pull request and someone is adding new dependencies to your system you should
have a look and say is the library or dependency that's being introduced trusted is it popular is it well
maintained and very importantly do we actually need it maybe all it does is offers four lines of code and we could
use our own code to do that instead of pulling in a third-party dependency

now the wrong people in the security mindset are often kind of malicious attackers someone trying to get to some

showing information to people who weren't specifically looking for it but now have got it and so the classic example here is a user let's take our

know that's kind of a personal reputation risk I guess but you can imagine Financial scenarios that are
similar um and this often happens due to caching issues so in the modern web it's super
important that we cache information because people want information quickly but we need to be careful that we're caching that information in the correct
way so um if your data is caching things that it
shouldn't for example a person's very specific dating profile that's bad
because we're going to be returning that to someone else so you should understand when you're reviewing code what the default caching behavior is for your
application very often the default caching behavior is performance oriented so if systems cache things aggressively
and so when you're busy working with data you need to think very carefully about how you interact with that my
personal recommendation would be to rather have a slow website than an insecure website from the performance of
cache optimization so rather have your default caching behaviors be conservative
and then do something to make sure that oh because you can look at it at a pull request and say oh well hang on we
